briefdescription.para: Typedef to Traits::Point.
Typedef to Traits::Ellipse.

detaileddescription.para: If you are using the predefined traits class CGAL::Min_ellipse_2_traits_2<K>, you can access the coefficients of the ellipse, see the documentation of CGAL::Min_ellipse_2_traits_2<K> and the example below.

briefdescription.para: Non-mutable model of the STL concept BidirectionalIterator with value type Point.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the points of the smallest enclosing ellipse.

briefdescription.para: Non-mutable model of the STL concept RandomAccessIterator with value type Point.

detaileddescription.para: Used to access the support points of the smallest enclosing ellipse.

description.para: A Min_ellipse_2 object can be created from an arbitrary point set $ P$ and by specialized construction methods expecting no, one, two, three, four or five points as arguments.
The latter methods can be useful for reconstructing $ me(P)$ from a given support set $ S$ of $ P$.

memberdef.argsstring: (InputIterator first, InputIterator last, bool randomize, Random &random=get_default_random(), const Traits &traits=Traits())
memberdef.name: Min_Ellipse_2

briefdescription.para: initializes min_ellipse to $ me(P)$ with $ P$ being the set of points in the range [first,last).

detaileddescription.para:
If randomize is true, a random permutation of $ P$ is computed in advance, using the random numbers generator random. Usually, this will not be necessary, however, the algorithm's efficiency depends on the order in which the points are processed, and a bad order might lead to extremely poor performance (see example below).
InputIterator
is a model of InputIterator with Point as value type.

briefdescription.para: creates a variable min_ellipse of type Min_ellipse_2.

detaileddescription.para:
It is initialized to $ me(\emptyset)$, the empty set.
min_ellipse.is_empty() = true.

briefdescription.para: initializes min_ellipse to $ me(\{p\})$, the set $ \{p\}$.
initializes min_ellipse to $ me(\{p,q\})$, the set $ \{ (1-\lambda) p + \lambda q \mid 0 \leq \lambda \leq 1 \}$

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p1, const Point &p2, const Point &p3, const Traits &traits=Traits())
memberdef.name: Min_ellipse_2

briefdescription.para: initializes min_ellipse to $ me(\{p1,p2,p3\})$.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p1, const Point &p2, const Point &p3, const Point &p4, const Traits &traits=Traits())
memberdef.name: Min_ellipse_2

briefdescription.para: initializes min_ellipse to $ me(\{p1,p2,p3,p4\})$.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p1, const Point &p2, const Point &p3, const Point &p4, const Point &p5, const Traits &traits=Traits())
memberdef.name: Min_ellipse_2

briefdescription.para: initializes min_ellipse to $ me(\{p1,p2,p3,p4,p5\})$.
returns the number of points of min_ellipse, i.e. $ |P|$.
returns the number of support points of min_ellipse, i.e. $ |S|$.
returns an iterator referring to the first point of min_ellipse.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns an iterator referring to the first support point of min_ellipse.
returns the corresponding past-the-end iterator.
returns the i-th support point of min_ellipse.

detaileddescription.para:
Between two modifying operations (see below) any call to min_ellipse.support_point(i) with the same i returns the same point.
$ 0 \leq i<$ min_ellipse.number_of_support_points().

briefdescription.para: returns the current ellipse of min_ellipse.

description.para: By definition, an empty Min_ellipse_2 has no boundary and no bounded side, i.e. its unbounded side equals the whole space $ \E^2$.

briefdescription.para: returns CGAL::ON_BOUNDED_SIDE, CGAL::ON_BOUNDARY, or CGAL::ON_UNBOUNDED_SIDE iff p lies properly inside, on the boundary of, or properly outside of min_ellipse, resp.
returns true, iff p lies properly inside min_ellipse.
returns true, iff p lies on the boundary of min_ellipse.
returns true, iff p lies properly outside of min_ellipse.
returns true, iff min_ellipse is empty (this implies degeneracy).
returns true, iff min_ellipse is degenerate, i.e. if min_ellipse is empty, equal to a single point or equal to a segment, equivalently if the number of support points is less than 3.

description.para: New points can be added to an existing min_ellipse, allowing to build $ me(P)$ incrementally, e.g.
if $ P$ is not known in advance. Compared to the direct creation of $ me(P)$, this is not much slower, because the construction method is incremental itself.

briefdescription.para: inserts p into min_ellipse and recomputes the smallest enclosing ellipse.
inserts the points in the range [first,last) into min_ellipse and recomputes the smallest enclosing ellipse by calling insert(p) for each point p in [first,last).

parameterdescription.para: is a model of InputIterator with Point as value type.

briefdescription.para: deletes all points in min_ellipse and sets min_ellipse to the empty set.

description.para: An object min_ellipse is valid, iff

min_ellipse contains all points of its defining set $ P$,
min_ellipse is the smallest ellipse spanned by its support set $ S$, and
$ S$ is minimal, i.e. no support point is redundant.
Note: In this release only the first item is considered by the validity check.

briefdescription.para: returns true, iff min_ellipse contains all points of its defining set $ P$.

detaileddescription.para: If verbose is true, some messages concerning the performed checks are written to standard error stream. The second parameter level is not used, we provide it only for consistency with interfaces of other classes.

briefdescription.para: returns a const reference to the traits class object.
writes min_ellipse to output stream os.

detaileddescription.para: An overload of operator<< must be defined for Point (and for Ellipse, if pretty printing is used).

briefdescription.para: reads min_ellipse from input stream is.

detaileddescription.para: An overload of operator>> must be defined for Point.

briefdescription.para: An object of the class Min_ellipse_2 is the unique ellipse of smallest area enclosing a finite (multi)set of points in two-dimensional euclidean space $ \E^2$.

detaileddescription.para: For a point set $ P$ we denote by $ me(P)$ the smallest ellipse that contains all points of $ P$. Note that $ me(P)$ can be degenerate, i.e. $ me(P)=\emptyset$ if $ P=\emptyset$, $ me(P)=\{p\}$ if $ P=\{p\}$, and $ me(P) = \{ (1-\lambda)p + \lambda q \mid 0 \leq \lambda \leq 1 \}$ if $ P=\{p,q\}$.

An inclusion-minimal subset $ S$ of $ P$ with $ me(S)=me(P)$ is called a support set, the points in $ S$ are the support points. A support set has size at most five, and all its points lie on the boundary of $ me(P)$. In general, neither the support set nor its size are necessarily unique.

The underlying algorithm can cope with all kinds of input, e.g. $ P$ may be empty or points may occur more than once. The algorithm computes a support set $ S$ which remains fixed until the next insert or clear operation.

Traits
must be a model for MinEllipse2Traits.
We provide the model CGAL::Min_ellipse_2_traits_2<K> using the two-dimensional CGAL kernel.
We implement the incremental algorithm of Welzl, with move-to-front heuristic [16], using the primitives as described in [4], [3]. The whole implementation is described in [6].

If randomization is chosen, the creation time is almost always linear in the number of points. Access functions and predicates take constant time, inserting a point might take up to linear time, but substantially less than computing the new smallest enclosing ellipse from scratch. The clear operation and the check for validity each takes linear time.

To illustrate the usage of Min_ellipse_2 and to show that randomization can be useful in certain cases, we give an example. The example also shows how the coefficents of the constructed ellipse can be accessed.
